Award.AwardTitle: STARSS: Small: Simulation-Based Verification of EM Side-Channel Attack Resilience of Embedded Cryptographic Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The widely used encryption algorithms, based both on private- and public-key cryptography, provide provable security guarantees against attacks under an abstract model of computation. In reality, physical systems leak information and the adversarial access is not completely captured by the abstractions in the standard model. Attacks that exploit a physically observable signal, such as power, timing, or electromagnetic (EM) radiation, are known as side-channel attacks. They present a formidable challenge to ensuring the security of existing cryptographic applications. Embedded systems are especially vulnerable to side-channel attacks as they can easily become physically accessible to an attacker and thus permit extensive probing. This project focuses on a side-channel attack based on the electromagnetic radiation analysis.

The project aims to provide the designers of embedded cryptosystems with the ability to analyze the resilience of their designs at design-time. The project develops predictive models and algorithms that enable the computation of EM emanation profiles of information-bearing blocks and thus enables design-time investigation of embedded cryptosystem vulnerability to EM side-channel with sufficient accuracy at acceptable computational costs. The project relies on the recent advances in integral-equation based techniques for EM simulation to enable the needed level of simulation accuracy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The widely used encryption algorithms, based both on private- and public-key cryptography, are vulnerable to attacks that exploit information leaked by their physical implementations. Such side-channel attacks present a formidable challenge to ensuring the security of existing cryptographic applications. Embedded systems are especially vulnerable to side-channel attacks as they can easily become physically accessible to an attacker and thus permit extensive probing. This project has focused on a side-channel attack based on the localized electromagnetic (EM) radiation analysis. Because the attack utilizes high resolution EM probes to localize and exploit information leakage in sub-circuits of a system, it is able to provide information not available in traditional EM and power consumption attacks. The project has expanded the state-of-the-art in this area via three inter-related and overlapping contributions aimed at developing computational tools, enhancing empirical characterization methods, and identifying new design-for-security techniques.

The first contribution focused on the critical need of providing the designers of embedded cryptosystems with the ability to analyze the resilience of their designs at design-time. Predictive simulation of EM attacks is computationally taxing as it requires transient circuit and EM simulation for a large number of encryptions, with high modeling accuracy, and high spatial and temporal resolution of EM fields. The project has introduced a number of computational techniques that jointly have resulted in a computational platform for EM side-channel attack analysis based on commercial EDA tools while achieving a speed-up of more than three orders of magnitude compared to conventional sequential simulation.

The second contribution has led to enhanced strategies for empirical characterization of EM side-channel vulnerabilities of embedded devices. Computational techniques rely on careful experimental characterization which are time-consuming because measured fields vary with probe parameters as well as the data being encrypted. As a result, identifying the optimal configurations requires searching among a large number of possible configurations. The research under this proposal has identified an adaptive acquisition protocol to rapidly identify optimal near-field measurement configurations thus reducing acquisition time by 35? compared to an exhaustive search for the optimal configuration.

The third contribution has focused on developing a countermeasure for localized EM attacks that exploit spatial information leakage in sub-circuits of a system and are more effective than traditional EM and power attacks. The project has developed a technique that performs randomization of physical placement of sensitive data to hardware components in a high-performance implementation of a symmetric cipher. This randomization results in a significant reduction of exploitable leakage improving the security of the implementation.
